awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Carbon Nanohorns: Adsorption Kinetics and Equilibrium, Experiments and Simulations
awd_abstract_narration:
****NON-TECHNICAL ABSTRACT****

Carbon nanohorns are hollow, closed "containers" with widths one hundred thousand times smaller than a hair.  Their interior is separated from the exterior by a one-atom-thick wall of carbon atoms.  Nanohorns group into tiny balls.  The spaces between nanohorns in the balls are conically shaped.  When a gas is placed in contact with these balls, it goes into these conical spaces and remains there (like liquid absorbed by a sponge).  If the walls of the nanohorns are punctured, the gas will also fill the interior of the nanohorns.  This project investigates, through experiment and computer simulation, how gases collect in the nanohorn balls; how fast gases penetrate into the spaces available; and how the amount of gas collected varies with gas species, temperature, and pressure.  Confining gases into these tiny "sponges" will make them behave differently from three-dimensional matter.  It can also lead to new technologies for gas storage, selective gas trapping, and gas mixture separation.  In this project one post-doctoral researcher, two graduate students, and several undergraduates will be trained in techniques used for studying the flow and storage of gases in porous materials.  Student exchanges between Howard University and Southern Illinois University will enhance the training efforts of the project. 

****TECHNICAL ABSTRACT****

This project aims at carrying out experimental and computer simulations of the thermodynamics and kinetics of gas adsorption on carbon nanohorns.  Nanohorns are a form of single-wall carbon.  Unlike nanotubes, nanohorns form spherical aggregates.  The interstitial spaces between nanohorns in the spherical aggregates form quasi-conical pores, readily available for adsorption.  The interior hollow space of a nanohorn can be made accessible by oxidizing its walls.  Gases adsorbed on the pores in the aggregates provide realizations of matter in less-than-three dimensions, making these systems interesting from a fundamental perspective.  The wide entrances of the quasi-conical pores provide favorable adsorption kinetics, and the pores have high binding energies; both characteristics are useful for applications to gas purification, separation, and storage.  The results obtained will yield useful insights into the kinetics and thermodynamics of gas adsorption on porous media.  They may also lead to new technologies for gas storage, selective gas trapping, and gas mixture separation.  The project provides excellent opportunities for training one post-doctoral researcher, two graduate students, and several undergraduates, in the experimental and computational aspects of gas adsorption in porous materials.

por.por_cntn:
Electron microscope images show that individual carbon nanohorns are formed by a one-atom-thick carbon sheet, forming a closed structure similar to a non-uniform, bi-lobar (i.e., cylinder-like) or tri-lobar (3-point-Ninja-star-like) object, in which each lobe ends in a conical tip, the "horn". Compared to nanotubes, carbon nanohorns are relatively shorter and wider, and have more defects. Nanohorns aggregate forming more or less spherical arrangements, in which the horn tips point radially outwards, resembling that in which the petals point radially out in a dahlia (for this reason they are known as "dahlia-like" nanohorn aggregates).

The aim of this project was to conduct an experimental and computer simulation study of the films formed by gases adsorbed on aggregates of carbon nanohorns. The goals of this combined approach were to determine how the films approached adsorption equilibrium (i.e., their kinetics of adsorption) and the properties of the films after equilibrium they had reached equilibrium (i.e., their thermodynamics of adsorption); and, to develop a structural model for the aggregates of carbon nanohorns capable of accurately describing the properties that had been determined for them in adsorption and in electron microscopy studies.

The structure of the carbon nanohorn aggregates makes them interesting objects on which to study adsorption because the spaces at the interior of the lobes and between the lobes in the aggregates effectively behave like pores in the arrangement, making this a new form of carbon-based porous material. At the same time, this lack of structural regularity makes them challenging to model with computer simulations. We achieved both the experimental and the computer-simulation goals of this project.

We developed a computational model for carbon nanohorn aggregates that accounts well for both the results of adsorption experiments that we performed as well as for the results of obtained from the electron microscopy studies of the aggregates. Our approach includes the appropriate geometry of the dahlia-like aggregates and, hence, the pore structure in them.

We have studied, through experiments and simulations, the equilibrium films on aggregates of chemically opened and as-produced carbon nanohorn aggregates. We have determined the strength of the binding of various adsorbed gases to the aggregates, and how the strength of the binding changes when the amount of gas adsorbed on the nanohorns is varied. Our studies were performed using spherical atomic adsorbates (neon, argon), effectively spherical molecules (CF4), hydrocarbons (ethane) and carbon dioxide. Our measurements on CO2 were conducted in part to explore if carbon nanohorns could be an appropriate material for the storage and sequestration of this gas; we found that the strength of the binding CO2 on carbon nanohorns is not adequate for this application.  

The third aspect of our work was our focus on the kinetics of adsorption, i.e., how a dose of gas admitted into the cell containing the nanohorns approaches adsorption equilibrium on that sorbent. We have found a variety of different behaviors with respect to how equilibrium is approached on the nanohorns as a function of sorbent loading: for spherical adsorbates we found that equilibration times become shorter as more gas is sorbed on the nanohorns, while the opposite behavior is observed for carbon dioxide (equilibration times increase as sorbent loading increases). What determines how long it takes for equilibrium to be reached includes: the chemical species, size and shape of the gas molecules; whether the molecules have or do not have electric moments; the shape and size of the pores in the nanohorns; the amount of gas already adsorbed on the nanohorns; and, the temperature. Transient configuration profiles and a detailed analysis of the role of the molecular interactions derived from the simulations were particularly useful to understand this dependence. An important aspect of our measurements of the approach to equilibrium is that they demonstrate explicitly the need of using long time intervals for ensuring equilibration (typically of the order of hours); this is a point that is often overlooked. 

A relative large group of people received training as a result of their participation in both aspects (experiments and computer simulations) of this project: One post-doctoral researcher, four Master degree students, three doctoral students, and three undergraduates participated in the project. They included two women (the post-doctoral researcher and one undergraduate) and one Latino (one of the undergraduates).

As part of the work on this project a course on experimental vacuum techniques and gas adsorption measurements was developed. The course was delivered as a part of a larger set of lectures on adsorption on carbon nanotubes, carbon nanohorns and other nanostructured sorbents at the Universidad Nacional de San Luis in Argentina (where the PI was sponsored as a Fulbright Specialist). The course has been used already in the training of graduate and undergraduate students at SIU.
